title: 110_hr955
content:
The Act is titled the "Clean, Learn, Educate, Abolish, Neutralize, and Undermine Production of Methamphetamines Act" or "CLEAN-UP of Methamphetamines Act". It includes a table of contents and falls under the category of environmental protection. Sec. 101-104 of the CLEAN-UP of Methamphetamines Act address the response to environmental hazards from illegal methamphetamine production on agricultural lands. This includes grants for government and private response, designation of by-products as hazardous materials, and assistance for law enforcement in cleanup and disposal of methamphetamine labs. Sec. 105 of the CLEAN-UP of Methamphetamines Act establishes a grant program to help law enforcement agencies cover costs related to complying with Federal laws on methamphetamine lab cleanup. TITLE III--ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 201-203 focus on studying health effects of methamphetamine exposure, grants for educational programs on prevention and treatment, and local grants for treatment of methamphetamine abuse. Authorization of appropriations for methamphetamine laboratory seizure statistics, COPS grants, expansion of the methamphetamine Hot Spots program, clandestine laboratory training, and addressing environmental hazards associated with illegal manufacture of methamphetamine on Department of Agriculture and Department of the Interior lands. The Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary of the Interior may conduct environmental cleanup programs on National Forest System lands and National Park System lands contaminated with hazardous substances from illegal methamphetamine production. $15,000,000 is authorized for these programs. Additionally, a grant program is established to assist state and local governments and private entities in responding to environmental hazards from methamphetamine production on agricultural lands. The Secretary of Agriculture may provide grants to clean up contaminated agricultural lands from methamphetamine production. $15,000,000 is authorized for these grants. By-products of methamphetamine labs are designated as hazardous materials under certain acts. The Secretary of Transportation and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency have the authority to designate by-products of methamphetamine production as hazardous materials and waste to protect the environment and impose penalties on those operating illegal methamphetamine laboratories. The Administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration will submit a list of harmful by-products from methamphetamine production to the Secretary of Transportation and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to prevent environmental damage. The list will be updated annually to reflect changes in the production process. The Administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration will submit a list of harmful by-products from methamphetamine production to the Secretary of Transportation and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency for designation within 18 months of the enactment of the Act. If revisions are made to the list, additional designations must be completed within 18 months of the revised list submission. SEC. 104. Grant program to assist law enforcement agencies in the safe identification, cleanup, and disposal of methamphetamine laboratories. The Secretary of Labor will provide grants to State and local law enforcement agencies for training and equipment related to identifying, cleaning up, and disposing of methamphetamine laboratories. Grant funds can cover costs for training and equipment provided by public agencies or private organizations. The Secretary of Labor may establish rules for this program, and $20,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2008. SEC. 105. Grant program to assist law enforcement agencies in meeting the costs of complying with federal laws on methamphetamine laboratory cleanup and disposal. The Secretary of Labor will provide grants to State and local law enforcement agencies for this purpose, with $10,000,000 authorized for fiscal year 2008. Rulemaking may be prescribed by the Secretary of Labor. SEC. 106. Study of environmental impact of methamphetamine laboratories on agriculture required by the EPA. $1,000,000 authorized for fiscal year 2008. 

TITLE II--Education, prevention, and treatment. SEC. 201. Study on health effects of exposure to unlawful manufacture of methamphetamine. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on the contamination of food, water, air, soil, and equipment by methamphetamine manufacturing. The study will also assess any adverse health effects on individuals exposed to the manufacturing process or contaminated matter. A report on the findings will be submitted to Congress within one year. SEC. 202 amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to allocate $20,000,000 for grants in fiscal year 2008 for educational programs on prevention and treatment of methamphetamine abuse. It also establishes a grant program for education on prevention and treatment of methamphetamine abuse. SEC. 4146 establishes a grant program to educate students on prevention and treatment of methamphetamine abuse. Grants are available to State agencies, local educational agencies, and nonprofit organizations on a competitive basis. Applicants must submit an application to the Secretary to receive a grant. SEC. 514C amends the Public Health Service Act to provide local grants for the treatment of methamphetamine abuse and related conditions. The Secretary may grant funds to political subdivisions and nonprofit entities for treating methamphetamine abuse. Grants can also be used to treat children for health issues from methamphetamine exposure during manufacturing. The term 'associated contaminated matter' in the context of manufacturing methamphetamine refers to substances like food, water, air, soil, equipment, or other materials that are contaminated with harmful substances due to their proximity to the manufacturing process. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2008, with at least $2,500,000 reserved for children. TITLE III--ENFORCEMENT

SEC. 301. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS FOR METHAMPHETAMINE LABORATORY SEIZURE STATISTICS: $2,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2008 for the collection of methamphetamine laboratory seizure statistics by the El Paso Intelligence Center (EPIC) of the Department of Justice.

SEC. 302. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS FOR COPS GRANTS. SEC. 302. Authorization of $20,000,000 for COPS grants in fiscal year 2008 for training State and local prosecutors and law enforcement agents in methamphetamine offenses. $5,000,000 allocated for rural communities, and $2,000,000 for DEA reimbursement of training expenses. SEC. 303 expands the Methamphetamine Hot Spots Program to include personnel and equipment for enforcement, prosecution, and environmental cleanup of methamphetamine-affected areas. SEC. 304 authorizes appropriations for clandestine laboratory training. In addition to funds for the Clandestine Laboratory Training Facility, $10,000,000 is authorized for training law enforcement personnel nationwide. Congress states concerns about the availability and illegal importation of pseudoephedrine from Canada. The Congress acknowledges the control efforts on pseudoephedrine in the US but notes the presence of large containers from Canada at methamphetamine sites, indicating high demand despite enforcement actions. The Congress urges Canada to take immediate action to address the widespread availability of pseudoephedrine and its illegal importation into the United States. Canada lacks a comprehensive legislative framework to tackle the trafficking problem.
